message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms and lab findings consistent with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). JIA is a systemic autoimmune disease, and uveitis, inflammation of the eye, is a common extra-articular complication. Blindness is a potential complication if left untreated. Therefore, option (D) is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The child has symptoms and laboratory findings consistent with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). JIA is associated with uveitis, which can lead to blindness. There is no indication of airway obstruction, inflammation of sacroiliac joints or coronary artery aneurysm in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s laboratory results reveal a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test, which indicates an autoimmune disorder. Among the options, ANA positivity is most strongly associated with uveitis, a form of eye inflammation that can lead to blindness. Airway obstruction, inflammation of sacroiliac joints, and coronary artery aneurysm are not usually associated with ANA positivity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory results suggest systemic idiopathic juvenile arthritis, which can lead to uveitis and blindness as a complication. None of the other options are commonly associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), and the elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and antinuclear antibodies support this diagnosis. One of the potential complications of JIA is uveitis, which can cause blindness if left untreated, making (D) the correct answer. Airway obstruction and inflammation of sacroiliac joints are not commonly associated with JIA. Coronary artery aneurysm is a complication of Kawasaki disease, not JIA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory studies are consistent with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). JIA can lead to inflammation in almost any joint in the body, including those in the eyes, which can result in uveitis and blindness as a complication. Airway obstruction is not typically associated with JIA. Inflammation of sacroiliac joints is more commonly seen in ankylosing spondylitis. Coronary artery aneurysm is a complication of Kawasaki disease, which typically presents with fever, rash, and conjunctivitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This patient has symptoms of juvenile idiopathic arthritis, which can increase the risk of uveitis and subsequently, blindness if left untreated. None of the other options are associated with this particular condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). JIA can cause inflammation of the eye, which if untreated, can lead to blindness. Therefore, the patient is at increased risk for blindness if left untreated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), specifically the oligoarticular subtype. Patients with JIA are at risk for developing uveitis, which can lead to blindness if left untreated. Therefore, the most likely complication in this patient is blindness. The other options are not associated with JIA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory results suggest Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis, which can cause uveitis, leading to blindness. Airway obstruction, inflammation of sacroiliac joints, and coronary artery aneurysm are not commonly associated with Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis.
